block.p: Albania announced a series of laws that may bring about far-reaching liberalization in the lives of the 3.3 million citizens of the most restrictive of European Communist countries.
Albania announced a series of laws that may bring about far-reaching liberalization in the lives of the 3.3 million citizens of the most restrictive of European Communist countries.
Albania announced a series of laws that may bring about far-reaching liberalization in the lives of the 3.3 million citizens of the most restrictive of European Communist countries.

Poland's revolution has stagnated, Lech Walesa declared. The leader of the Solidarity trade union pledged to foment ''permanent political war'' that would shake the Government he helped create last year.
The traditional parade in Red Square in Moscow honoring the Allied victory in World War II had a hollow ring, particularly for those it was meant to honor.
Lithuanian compromise urged by British leader
NATO splits on removing weapons from West Germany

Thousands of South Korean students marched through the streets of Seoul and other major cities to protest the apparent consolidation of power by a new political party controlled by President Roh Tae Woo.
An international meeting in Geneva sharply criticized a White House decision to oppose financial aid for developing countries to phase out chemicals that are destroying the earth's ozone layer.
News analysis: Israel has emerged as the beneficiary of changing times in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, while the Arab world confronts the losses.
U.S. and Iran in accord on 2,500 small claims
A murder trial in Johannesburg is focusing unsolicited new attention on Winnie Mandela, the apartheid foe and wife of the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela.
Pope challenges rich nations to start sharing
Salvador rebels make new peace offer
Thailand's fast-growing economy is closely tied to Japanese investment. With a mixture of elation and misgivings, Thais sometimes talk about their country as Japan's newest ''economic colony.''
Kabul journal: Afghan can thank his four-star aide for power
The F.C.C. has awarded licenses for the creation and operation of a new type of cellular telephone network that will greatly expand the number of callers who can use cellular service simultaneously.

A computerized information system used by border agents to screen visitors to the U.S. is so flawed that major drug traffickers and other criminals may be able to cross the nation's borders without detection, Federal investigators say.

Democratic Congressional leaders told President Bush that they would accept his invitation to begin ''good faith'' budget negotiations, but hours later fierce skirmishing erupted in Congress over who would take the blame for any tax increases.
News analysis: The issue is not so much taxes as blame
Economic analysis: Economists see need for budget deal
Politicians seek sign from California on taxes
Change in Social Security for women is urged
The Senate Ethics Committee voted to conduct a full investigation of Senator Dave Durenberger's handling of Minneapolis condominium.
Bush discussion of contras is denied
The American tuna fleet was jolted by a decision last month by the nation's three largest sellers of canned tuna to stop selling fish caught in nets that also trap and kill dolphins.
Residents along the Trinity River in Texas, for the fourth time in a year, are waiting to lose everything to a flood. This torrent is expected to be the worst by far.
To save fish, judge curbs lowering of lake
Old error stalls focusing of space telescope
Mixed results reported for experimental AIDS drug
High death toll seen from passive smoking
California opens new offensive on fruit fly
Jackson assails Harvard Law School at rally

The New York City Council is struggling to use its greatly expanded powers. But its new muscle-flexing has been stymied by its own members, many of whom are mired in the sloppy, sleepy style of the past.
The New York Health Commissioner is abolishing his agency's AIDS-prevention program for drug abusers, who are now the main source of AIDS cases in the city.
Albany will probably not use layoffs to close a $4 billion budget gap, even though New York employs more workers in relation to its population than any of the 10 largest states.
Albany re-examines plans for sales taxes
Connecticut assembly approves 14-day delay for gun purchases
Rent increases set by board anger landlords

Senator Bill Bradley's opponent this fall will probably be Christine Todd Whitman, a former president of the State Board of Public Utilities and a member of one of New Jersey's most prominent Republican families.
Pollution has eased in Staten Island since the eastbound toll of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was removed in 1986. But pollution and traffic have increased significantly in Manhattan and Brooklyn.
Tension, and attention, outside Brooklyn court
Dinkins steps up criticism of Brooklyn protesters
Judge asks Cuomo to act in Westchester case
Dean is indicted on sex charges in abuse of girl
Another student faces indictment in St. John's case
Breslin suspension a victory for minority journalists
It's brutal. It's ruthless. It's flea-market season
Staining spool furniture: just the right twist
New York's granddaddy of open-air selling
Chairs that sit well with active people
Word and Image: ''Search for Modern China''
Depression rates for girls linked to self-image
Test backs theory on sugar influencing child behavior
Basketball: Knicks don't like what they see on film

Parental leave: leave it at that

Julian L. Simon: More immigration can cut the deficit
